body: Dropout acts as identity during inference time. It's set in training mode only in the scope of autograd.record() in imperative case, or usually set by module in symbolic case.
@piiswrong  we did not convert the names to camel cases and just use  original names.

autograd is not under mxnet yet in 0.10.0. It's under mxnet.contrib.autograd, and may have different APIs. To follow the tutorial, you will need 0.10.1, which is available by building from source or installing the nightly build from pip with 'pip --pre' switch on.
@szha,thank you very much.Now everything is fine.
problem solved

or you can change in setup.py :
```python
      packages=[
          'mxnet', 'mxnet.module', 'mxnet._ctypes', 'mxnet.rnn',
          'mxnet._cy2', 'mxnet._cy3', 'mxnet.notebook', 'mxnet.contrib',
          ],
```
by
```python
      packages=[
          'mxnet', 'mxnet.module', 'mxnet._ctypes', 'mxnet.rnn',
          'mxnet._cy2', 'mxnet._cy3', 'mxnet.notebook', 'mxnet.contrib',
          'mxnet.gluon', 'mxnet.gluon.nn', 'mxnet.gluon.rnn'
          ],
```
It should work

I am having the same issue - I would really like to be able to share parameters across two modules, because each module will be reading from a distinct data stream and training a distinct network with only some shared components. A somewhat minimal example appears below:
```
import logging
import mxnet as mx

mnist = mx.test_utils.get_mnist()

batch_size = 100
train_iter = mx.io.NDArrayIter(mnist['train_data'], mnist['train_label'], batch_size, shuffle=True)
val_iter = mx.io.NDArrayIter(mnist['test_data'], mnist['test_label'], batch_size)
data = mx.sym.var('data')
data = mx.sym.flatten(data=data)

# Set up variables to share parameters for all layers
w1 = mx.sym.Variable('1_weight')
w2 = mx.sym.Variable('2_weight')
w3 = mx.sym.Variable('3_weight')
b1 = mx.sym.Variable('1_bias')
b2 = mx.sym.Variable('2_bias')
b3 = mx.sym.Variable('3_bias')

# Build network 1 with explicit weight pointers
fc1 = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=data, num_hidden=128, weight=w1, bias=b1)
act1 = mx.sym.Activation(data=fc1, act_type="relu")
fc2 = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=act1, num_hidden=64, weight=w2, bias=b2)
act2 = mx.sym.Activation(data=fc2, act_type="relu")
fc3 = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=act2, num_hidden=10, weight=w3, bias=b3)
mlp = mx.sym.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc3, name='softmax')
# Build module 1
mlp_model = mx.mod.Module(symbol=mlp, context=mx.cpu())

# Now build a second, identical graph that shares the same weight pointers
fc1s = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=data, num_hidden=128, weight=w1, bias=b1)
act1s = mx.sym.Activation(data=fc1s, act_type="relu")
fc2s = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=act1s, num_hidden=64, weight=w2, bias=b2)
act2s = mx.sym.Activation(data=fc2s, act_type="relu")
fc3s = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=act2s, num_hidden=10, weight=w3, bias=b3)
mlps = mx.sym.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc3s, name='softmax')
# Build module 2
mlp_models = mx.mod.Module(symbol=mlps, context=mx.cpu())


# Train module 1
logging.getLogger().setLevel(logging.DEBUG)  # logging to stdout
print("\n===Training module1===\n")
mlp_model.fit(train_iter,  # train data
              eval_data=val_iter,  # validation data
              optimizer='sgd',  # use SGD to train
              optimizer_params={'learning_rate': 0.1},  # use fixed learning rate
              eval_metric='acc',  # report accuracy during training
              batch_end_callback=mx.callback.Speedometer(batch_size, 100),
              num_epoch=5)  # train for at most 10 dataset passes


# Train module 2
# We expect the shared module to start where the first module finished
print("\n===Training module2===\n")
mlp_models.shared_group = mlp_model._exec_group
mlp_models.fit(train_iter,  # train data
               eval_data=val_iter,  # validation data
               optimizer='sgd',  # use SGD to train
               optimizer_params={'learning_rate': 0.1},  # use fixed learning rate
               eval_metric='acc',  # report accuracy during training
               batch_end_callback=mx.callback.Speedometer(batch_size, 100),
               num_epoch=5)  # train for at most 10 dataset passes


# Making sure that fit doesn't always overwrite parameters by returning to module 1
print("\n===Training module1===\n")
mlp_model.fit(train_iter,  # train data
              eval_data=val_iter,  # validation data
              optimizer='sgd',  # use SGD to train
              optimizer_params={'learning_rate': 0.1},  # use fixed learning rate
              eval_metric='acc',  # report accuracy during training
              batch_end_callback=mx.callback.Speedometer(batch_size, 100),
              num_epoch=5)  # train for at most 10 dataset passes
```

aften the installationg of the OpenBLASS, run the command below to put the related lib file in to the path :/opt/OpenBLAS.
sudo make PREFIX=/opt/OpenBLAS install

THEN :

You need add /opt/openblas/lib to your LD path by doing this:  

export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$LD_LIBRARY_PATH:/usr/local/cuda/lib64/:usr/local/cuda/lib:/opt/OpenBLAS/lib:/usr/local/lib

or a simper solution, copy libopenblas.* from /opt/OpenBLAS/lib/ to /usr/local/lib64 (maybe /usr/local/lib) depends on your env. i don't have centos to check for sure.) after copy, run the command to refresh ld cacahe: "sudo ldconfig"

You need to use nightly pre-release to use gluon
pip install mxnet-xxx --pre --update

This is probably a question for Spark itself, not MXNet. The SVM you are referring to is in the old MLlib package, which is deprecated. The optimizer on it can be changed yes, but if you look at the type signatures it needs to extend the `Optimizer` class defined in MLlib. So you'd have to wrap the MXNet optimizers in an `Optimizer` class. I doubt that would be worth your time. SGD on Spark does not work well. The new ML package has a `LinearSVC` which uses quasi-newton methods which will be better on Spark.

Anyway, I think this issue should be closed.

To build mxnet with nnpack, I add these line in config.mk : 
```
# the additional link flags you want to add
ADD_LDFLAGS = -L/home/user/Documents/lib/NNPACK/lib

# the additional compile flags you want to add
ADD_CFLAGS = -I/home/user/Documents/lib/NNPACK/include -I/home/user/Documents/lib/NNPACK/third-party/pthreadpool/include
```
I made a dockerfile that compile mxnet with NNPACK. You can check if you do the same things. [here](https://github.com/edmBernard/DockerFiles/blob/master/cpu/nnpack_mxnet/Dockerfile)

```bash
# make standalone toolchain for android
android-ndk-r15/build/tools/make_standalone_toolchain.py --arch arm  --api 21 --install-dir android_compiler_armv7_32bit --stl=libc++ --force
export PATH=/home/user/Documents/lib/android_compiler_armv7_32bit/bin/:$PATH
# OpenBLAS
cd $PATH_TO_OPENBLAS
make TARGET=ARMV7 HOSTCC=gcc CC=arm-linux-androideabi-gcc NOFORTRAN=1 libs
# mxnet amalgamation
cd $PATH_TO_MXNET/amalgamation
# edit Makefile to add OpenBLAS Path
make mxnet_predict-all.cc
export CC=arm-linux-androideabi-clang
export CXX=arm-linux-androideabi-clang++
# fopen64 is not known, I replace them by std::fopen in mxnet_predict-all.cc
make ANDROID=1`
```

in my step make sure the x86 compiler is define before `make mxnet_predict-all.cc`   : 
```
export CC=/usr/bin/clang  # the normal one (x86)
export CXX=/usr/bin/clang++  # the normal one (x86)
make mxnet_predict-all.cc
export CC=arm-linux-androideabi-clang
export CXX=arm-linux-androideabi-clang++
# fopen64 is not known, I replace them by std::fopen in mxnet_predict-all.cc
make ANDROID=1
```

But I'm not sure if both network have different layer after shared layer, the weight transfers will work correctly (fit function will overwrite other layer with their default initialization). 
This method don't use the shared weight functionality of MXNet. 
EDIT1 : if both network have layer independent after shared layer, it seems to work too.

```python
# Train module 1
mlp_model = mx.mod.Module(symbol=mlp, context=mx.cpu())
logging.getLogger().setLevel(logging.DEBUG)  # logging to stdout
print("\n===Training module1===\n")
mlp_model.fit(train_iter,  # train data
              eval_data=val_iter,  # validation data
              optimizer='sgd',  # use SGD to train
              optimizer_params={'learning_rate': 0.1},  # use fixed learning rate
              eval_metric='acc',  # report accuracy during training
              batch_end_callback=mx.callback.Speedometer(batch_size, 100),
              num_epoch=1)  # train for at most 10 dataset passes


# Train module 2
# We expect the shared module to start where the first module finished
print("\n===Training module2===\n")
arg_param, aux_param = mlp_model.get_params()
mlp_models = mx.mod.Module(symbol=mlps, context=mx.cpu())
#mlp_models.shared_group = mlp_model._exec_group
mlp_models.fit(train_iter,  # train data
               eval_data=val_iter,  # validation data
               optimizer='sgd',  # use SGD to train
               optimizer_params={'learning_rate': 0.1},  # use fixed learning rate
               eval_metric='acc',  # report accuracy during training
               batch_end_callback=mx.callback.Speedometer(batch_size, 100),
               num_epoch=1,# train for at most 10 dataset passes
               arg_params=arg_param)  

arg_param, aux_param = mlp_models.get_params()
# Making sure that fit doesn't always overwrite parameters by returning to module 1
print("\n===Training module1===\n")
mlp_model.fit(train_iter,  # train data
              eval_data=val_iter,  # validation data
              optimizer='sgd',  # use SGD to train
              optimizer_params={'learning_rate': 0.1},  # use fixed learning rate
              eval_metric='acc',  # report accuracy during training
              batch_end_callback=mx.callback.Speedometer(batch_size, 100),
              num_epoch=1,
              arg_params=arg_param)  # train for at most 10 dataset passes
```

Hi @mli I want to implement CRelu structure. But when process the scale layer, I encounter an issue. 
That is after bn layer, the CRelu use a negative layer to it and concat the two layer[bn, -bn]. Then the subsequent layer is scale. So how to implement the scale layer alone with mxnet?

here : https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/tensor/matrix_op.cc#L442

When did you got this error ? Are you sure you properly compile and install mxnet ?
@Ldpe2G I'm using MxNet 0.10.0

As we have said in the document, we only provide pre-built pkgs for Windows and OSX. You are trying to install the source pkg for Linux, which is not provided.

If you are using OSX, you might have installed the R using brew which has different configurations from the official R for OSX. In this case, please try

```r
install.packages("mxnet", type = "el-capitan.binary")
```

The installation has only been tested with the official R installation from R-project website.
As the error says, check if the data is a list of NDArrays.
See: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/7166
